summary: It would have been nice if the NK was still alive and he was the one burning the city and causing Cersei to be scared. And then...
body:
It would have been nice if the NK was still alive and he was the one burning the city and causing Cersei to be scared. And then Jon and Dany have to destroy the city even more in order to stop him. And then the last episode was them dealing with all the death and consequences.

I can’t think about the shit pile that was 8x05 anymore, so I’m just imagining story lines I’d rather watch… Which is almost any other than what we’re getting.

summary: All the major Prophecies are coming true.
title: All the major Prophecies are coming true.
body:
I’m just realizing that the prophecies are all coming true. Just not in the way we thought. 

Warning: a couple of these are my own interpretations and one or two are still theories.

Dany’s prophecies from Mirri Maz Duur when she asked when Khal Drogo would be as he was before his injury.

When the sun rises in the West:
When the SON rises in the West, i.e. Jon, the son of Rhaegar. (I know I’m not the first one to this, but it’s worth repeating here.)

When the mountains blow in the wind like leaves:
The Mountain, who fell with his brother Sandor off the Red Keep, is now ash…blowing in the wind.

When the seas run dry:
Dany’s tears being completely spent.  An ocean of tears running dry. (my personal interpretation, take as you will)

When your womb quickens once again, he will return:
My theory is that Dany IS actually pregnant, but she will nonetheless be executed for war crimes against the people of King’s Landing. She will die, along with her unborn child, by Jon’s hand.  He will have no choice.  The final thing she sees is Khal Drogo, as he was, along with their infant son. This is what the final vision in the House of the Undying was previewing. It will be the last thing she imagines as her life is extinguished.

Azor Ahai (theory still, but very likely)

Azor Ahai is not Arya Stark because “the darkness” was never the Night King. It was Dany this whole time ;_;.  Azor Ahai’s birth circumstances were not supposed to be a literal birth of a child.  It simply meant he/she would come into being (awakening to a mindset) at the right moment.  “Amid salt and smoke” =  King’s Landing, after Daenerys’ rampage. Jon is Azor Ahai, he just wasn’t until the right time…as he watched amid salt (tears) and smoke (the ashen ruins of King’s Landing) he realized what Dany had become, and what he had to do. This is the real reason Jon was brought back by the Lord of Light.  It could only be him. (cries into a basket of kittens)

The Valonqar

“The Valonquar will wrap his hands around your pale neck and choke the life from you” Jaime did fulfill this, he just wasn’t responsible for killing Cersei out of some kind of hate.  Instead, he wrapped his hands around her (I believe you can see his hand around the back of her neck, forgive me I can’t find a screen cap) as the keep fell around them.

blog.name: waking-dreams-of-harmony
blog.title: Headcanon is the new reality...
blog.description:
Hi there! My name is Ellie! Welcome to my tumblr!  Just thought I'd add a few things to know about me and my blog! If my url gives you any clues, at the heart of this tumblr, I'm a proud Harmony shipper through and through. And while I do still reblog HHR and Dan and Emma content (and I always will) you will find that the majority of my focus has shifted to Jonerys (Jon x Daenerys from Game of Thrones). And while you might have to do a little deep blogging to find my reblogs on these, I also ship--both passionately and casually--Cesare x Lucrezia, Mulder x Scully, Lizzington for a while until tptb started to mess with it, Baker x Lawson (Bawson), all the Sense8 ships though Kalagang is my #1, Clint x Natasha (Clintasha), Jane x Thor (Fosterson), Darcy x Loki (Tasertricks), Darcy x Steve (Shieldshock), Kili x Tauriel (Kiliel), Superman x Wonder Woman (Superwonder), and more than I have space for or the memory to list. 
I do my best to tag every post so that if something is your notp, it's nsfw, or it's triggering, you can blacklist it. That said, if you follow me and there is something that you need tagged in order to make it a happy place for you to explore, come into my inbox and let me know :) You will also see a lot of politically charged reblogs in support of women, the queer/gender-queer and trans community, BLM, Muslims, POC, Jewish people, the mentally ill, and austistic people. I'm strongly pro choice, pro inter-sectional feminism, and refuse to call the angry cheeto currently living in the white house president. If anything like that offends you, this might not be the right blog for you.
Last little few things to throw out there: I'm 35, I plan to adopt at least 4 cats (or more) at some point and be that cat lady everyone's always whispering about, and I tend to greet and converse with everyone I meet like an overeager puppy. 
Whew! Sorry for the long intro folks! Please enjoy your time here, and remember, you're always welcome to come in and say hi!

summary: I think one of the really interesting things about Daenerys in Westeros is the idea of love and how she expected it but never...
body:
I think one of the really interesting things about Daenerys in Westeros is the idea of love and how she expected it but never got it, and i think thats why (even though its rushed), i am fascinated by this storyline, and i really love the way it is coming to fruition, because it is not just madness for the sake of madness, it is madness because Daenerys realises she has nothing left. 

In Essos, she got love because she liberated them, freeing them from slavers and tyrants, and so they loved her, but when she got to Westeros the first thing she did, really, was demand that all the people of Westeros bend or die, and I think she didn’t really understand what she was doing was not freedom, but subjugation. I think it’s so perfectly shown with the North. The Starks rode south from Castle Black, with the Nights Watch and a Wildling Army, and eventually the Knights fo the Vale, and they liberated the North. 

The parallel of the liberation of the Slave Cities in Essos and the Liberation of the North from the Boltons are so clear. The people of Essos called her Mhysa, and praised her as their queen, because she liberated them (ignoring the white saviour aspects, thats what it was. its problematic for other reasons but the idea of it is still what it is). 

The people of the North pledged themselves, acknowledging “No King but the King in the North, whose name is Stark”, calling Jon the King in the North, praising him as their King. 

The people of the North chose Jon and Sansa to lead them, which is paralleled beautifully to the line Missandei has in season 7 (gif by @gameofgifs) 

The people of Essos chose Daenerys, because she freed them, and they loved her. The people of the North chose Jon, and House Stark, because they freed them, and because they love the Starks. The Starks were always just and kind rulers, a great house, but also a good house, and the Northmen know it. They proclaimed Robb Stark, they followed Torren Stark many years before, they followed Ned as Warden of the North, and, when finally given the chance, they chose to follow Jon and Sansa again, to follow House Stark again. 

When Daenerys showed up, and got Jon to bend the knee, it was, in her eyes, her taking her rightful place as queen of these lands. But to the eyes of the Northmen, she was simply once again taking away their choice to be led by the King they chose. The people of the North don’t take kindly to her arrival because she comes North, with her massive and threatening army of incredibly skilled soldiers, and they have seen this story before. They have seen a King come North, and take their Warden South, never to return. They have seen men from other lands arrive, with armies, sent to protect them (don’t forget Ramsey was sent by Lord Bolton at the request of Robb Stark to free Winterfell from the Iron Born and return it to House Stark), who then conquered them, leading to a period of fear. They have seen what happens when a King in the North bows to a Targaryen, whether there was a time of peace or not, the North became a part of the Seven Kingdoms, and because of that, they have been at war for a long time. When Daenerys comes North, with her armies and her dragons, and the Northmen are then told that she is now their queen, she expects them to love her, to welcome her, because she arrived with Jon, and because she is there to rescue them from the Dead. But that was never what was going to happen. 

Daenerys expected love, but she was met with at best indifference, and at worst anger. She was met with the Wildlings, who didn’t give a damn about her, because they came for Jon, they fight for Jon, they are loyal to Jon. He is their King. She is met with Sansa, who fought for her home, who won it back from her captors, and who refuses to allow Northern Independence to be ripped away from her yet again. She is met with everything but love. Daenerys expected to come to Westeros, and to find a people waiting for their rightful queen to free them from tyranny. But instead, she met Lords and Kings of great houses and independent lands who did not need her to free their people, because their people loved them. 

I think when the Bells rang in KL, Dany finally saw it all for what it was. Even as much as the people hated Cersei, they did not ring the bells because they were rejoicing at the great Breaker of Chains coming to liberate them from tyranny. They did not ring the bells in celebration of their freedom from Cersei Lannister. They did not ring the bells to signal the arrival of the one true Queen. They looked upon a great dragon, burning ships and city walls and armies to the ground, perched upon the edges of their city, with giant armies at their gates, and they rang the bells in surrender, because they feared her. Daenerys listened to them, and heard the bells ringing, and realised that she was right. She had no love in Westeros, and, admittedly because of Cersei, she never would. The people of the North did not love her. The people of Kings Landing did not love her. I think the bells pushed Dany over the edge, not because of her grief, not because she was being framed as ‘irrational’, but because she realised that fear was all she would ever have here. No matter how good of a Queen she became, to take the Throne, to some degree, she would have to do something that would make her image in this land be a mirror of her father. To take the Iron Throne, she would have to be a Targaryen. To be the Queen, it would have to be with Fire and Blood. 

So she decides that if it must be fear, let it be the greatest fear the people have ever known. Let them cower at the thought of their Queen. Because if she is going to lead with fear, she might as well lead with terror, because who would fight against such a thing. 

Dany has been heading towards being Dark!Dany for a long time, and I honestly think that (even though it was rushed), it was done well. I think loosing Missandei (though an infuriating fridging) was meant to symbolise Daenerys finally giving up the delusion that she could be loved in Westeros. Dark!Daenerys comes from a realisation she is a Dragon, and she will take what is hers with Fire and Blood, and if it cannot be love… let it be terror.

reblog.comment:
I think one of the really interesting things about Daenerys in Westeros is the idea of love and how she expected it but never got it, and i think thats why (even though its rushed), i am fascinated by this storyline, and i really love the way it is coming to fruition, because it is not just madness for the sake of madness, it is madness because Daenerys realises she has nothing left. 

In Essos, she got love because she liberated them, freeing them from slavers and tyrants, and so they loved her, but when she got to Westeros the first thing she did, really, was demand that all the people of Westeros bend or die, and I think she didn’t really understand what she was doing was not freedom, but subjugation. I think it’s so perfectly shown with the North. The Starks rode south from Castle Black, with the Nights Watch and a Wildling Army, and eventually the Knights fo the Vale, and they liberated the North. 

The parallel of the liberation of the Slave Cities in Essos and the Liberation of the North from the Boltons are so clear. The people of Essos called her Mhysa, and praised her as their queen, because she liberated them (ignoring the white saviour aspects, thats what it was. its problematic for other reasons but the idea of it is still what it is). 

The people of the North pledged themselves, acknowledging “No King but the King in the North, whose name is Stark”, calling Jon the King in the North, praising him as their King. 

The people of the North chose Jon and Sansa to lead them, which is paralleled beautifully to the line Missandei has in season 7 (gif by @gameofgifs) 

The people of Essos chose Daenerys, because she freed them, and they loved her. The people of the North chose Jon, and House Stark, because they freed them, and because they love the Starks. The Starks were always just and kind rulers, a great house, but also a good house, and the Northmen know it. They proclaimed Robb Stark, they followed Torren Stark many years before, they followed Ned as Warden of the North, and, when finally given the chance, they chose to follow Jon and Sansa again, to follow House Stark again. 

When Daenerys showed up, and got Jon to bend the knee, it was, in her eyes, her taking her rightful place as queen of these lands. But to the eyes of the Northmen, she was simply once again taking away their choice to be led by the King they chose. The people of the North don’t take kindly to her arrival because she comes North, with her massive and threatening army of incredibly skilled soldiers, and they have seen this story before. They have seen a King come North, and take their Warden South, never to return. They have seen men from other lands arrive, with armies, sent to protect them (don’t forget Ramsey was sent by Lord Bolton at the request of Robb Stark to free Winterfell from the Iron Born and return it to House Stark), who then conquered them, leading to a period of fear. They have seen what happens when a King in the North bows to a Targaryen, whether there was a time of peace or not, the North became a part of the Seven Kingdoms, and because of that, they have been at war for a long time. When Daenerys comes North, with her armies and her dragons, and the Northmen are then told that she is now their queen, she expects them to love her, to welcome her, because she arrived with Jon, and because she is there to rescue them from the Dead. But that was never what was going to happen. 

Daenerys expected love, but she was met with at best indifference, and at worst anger. She was met with the Wildlings, who didn’t give a damn about her, because they came for Jon, they fight for Jon, they are loyal to Jon. He is their King. She is met with Sansa, who fought for her home, who won it back from her captors, and who refuses to allow Northern Independence to be ripped away from her yet again. She is met with everything but love. Daenerys expected to come to Westeros, and to find a people waiting for their rightful queen to free them from tyranny. But instead, she met Lords and Kings of great houses and independent lands who did not need her to free their people, because their people loved them. 

I think when the Bells rang in KL, Dany finally saw it all for what it was. Even as much as the people hated Cersei, they did not ring the bells because they were rejoicing at the great Breaker of Chains coming to liberate them from tyranny. They did not ring the bells in celebration of their freedom from Cersei Lannister. They did not ring the bells to signal the arrival of the one true Queen. They looked upon a great dragon, burning ships and city walls and armies to the ground, perched upon the edges of their city, with giant armies at their gates, and they rang the bells in surrender, because they feared her. Daenerys listened to them, and heard the bells ringing, and realised that she was right. She had no love in Westeros, and, admittedly because of Cersei, she never would. The people of the North did not love her. The people of Kings Landing did not love her. I think the bells pushed Dany over the edge, not because of her grief, not because she was being framed as ‘irrational’, but because she realised that fear was all she would ever have here. No matter how good of a Queen she became, to take the Throne, to some degree, she would have to do something that would make her image in this land be a mirror of her father. To take the Iron Throne, she would have to be a Targaryen. To be the Queen, it would have to be with Fire and Blood. 

So she decides that if it must be fear, let it be the greatest fear the people have ever known. Let them cower at the thought of their Queen. Because if she is going to lead with fear, she might as well lead with terror, because who would fight against such a thing. 

Dany has been heading towards being Dark!Dany for a long time, and I honestly think that (even though it was rushed), it was done well. I think loosing Missandei (though an infuriating fridging) was meant to symbolise Daenerys finally giving up the delusion that she could be loved in Westeros. Dark!Daenerys comes from a realisation she is a Dragon, and she will take what is hers with Fire and Blood, and if it cannot be love… let it be terror.

blog.name: khaleesirin
blog.title: Catleesi
blog.description: A 20 something year old caffeine induced tea loving Arendtian. Collects binders in real life and watches anime too seriously sometimes.

tags: please i spent my time watching this show talking about jonerys only one or two times
i won’t entertain any more conversation regarding jonerys in the tv show
summary: I completely agree with you about Tyrion and Dany. They ruined Jonerys for me. Dany's arc is tragic. Jon's arc is tragic. He'll...
question: I completely agree with you about Tyrion and Dany. They ruined Jonerys for me. Dany's arc is tragic. Jon's arc is tragic. He'll have to live knowing he killed the woman he loves. This is how it supposed to happen.
answer: When I said I couldn’t care less about Jonerys, I mean it. I don’t want to spend my time caring about Jon’s manpain over this whole tragedy. Or Dany’s supposed mental break because she got rejected by a man. How many times do I have to endure this kind of willy-nilly trope in my literature? You can have it. I don’t want it.

reblog.comment: When I said I couldn’t care less about Jonerys, I mean it. I don’t want to spend my time caring about Jon’s manpain over this whole tragedy. Or Dany’s supposed mental break because she got rejected by a man. How many times do I have to endure this kind of willy-nilly trope in my literature? You can have it. I don’t want it.

blog.name: asphodelesauvage
blog.title: United we stand, divided we fall
blog.description: Hi! I'm a French shipper, fanfiction writer and reader and aspiring novelist! I'm a Gryffindor who supports House Stark and my Queen in the North until the end of the world, and a huge fan of SPN, Teen Wolf, Sherlock,  Harry Potter, GoT, Good Omens and lots of others! 💜💙💚

summary: Sansa did not influence Daenerys’ actions and neither did she bring chaos in Westeros. Here is the proof.
title: Sansa did not influence Daenerys’ actions and neither did she bring chaos in Westeros. Here is the proof.
body:
A lot of anti-Sansa, pro-Daenerys people out there are blaming the burning of King’s Landing on Sansa, arguing that Sansa is responsible for the chaos because she tried to overthrow Daenerys and put her in such an emotional state that she listened to anger, and that Sansa, more generally, put Westeros into chaos.

But these people forget one thing - or I should say, one person. 

They forgot Bran. They forgot the Three-Eyed Raven.

They forgot the one person in all of Westeros who knows what was, what is and what will be.

And yes, Bran is cold and detached this season. But yet, he is not deprived of humanity. He told the North about the dragon being turned into a wight, so that the North would get ready in consequence, instead of having to face an unexpected enemy that would have destroyed the living in one minute. He told Theon he was a good man before he died, even though he had no obligation to do it, and did it only to bring closure and comfort to Theon, a lost brother who was dying for him.

Bran is still human. If he could have saved King’s Landing, he would have.

He saw the destruction of the city in his prophetic visions, after all. In his visions, he got to see the dragon flying over King’s Landing, and then the throne room completely destroyed. He knew what would happen. It means that he had the means to prevent it, if there was a possibility to avoid the massacre.

And yet, we have Bran actively encouraging (and even pushing) Sam to tell the truth to Jon, therefore basically pushing for Jon as a candidate to the Iron Throne. After what happened in the last episode, I think it’s clear that Bran knew what would happen, and that they needed someone else, someone better.

But since Bran would have prevented the massacre if he had the means to, it means that Jon’s identity has no connection with Daenerys burning King’s Landing. Bran is able to see the links connecting causes to consequences, he is able to see the great chain of events. And in the great chain events, Jon knowing his identity was not the cause of Daenerys’s actions.

And here comes Sansa. Bran, able to see the bigger picture, does not oppose to Jon’s telling Sansa the truth. Actually, he agrees to telling it himself. And moreover, he actually lets Jon decide. “It’s your call.” 

This is a key element. Jon is free to tell his sisters, because Bran can see that whether they knew or not, it had no importance. That Sansa knew and told people, or that she did not know and therefore told no one, had no impact in the grand scheme of things. 

There was no connection Sansa tells people -> people turn against Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. There wasn’t even a connection Jon knows -> Jon tells Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. And since Bran did nothing that could be associated, even remotely, with preventing the massacre - telling Jon to take Rhaegal with him, or to protect Missandei, or to tell Daenerys something in particular, or telling Tyrion what to do - I think it is safe to argue that there was nothing Bran could do. 

The burning of King’s Landing was unavoidable. 

Yes, I know, Daenerys felt overwhelmed by everything that was happening to her and all her losses and she wanted a bloodshed - but she was bound to burn King’s Landing anyway. She saw it in Qarth, years ago. Bran saw it, even though future is a tricky issue that can always change, because people’s decisions affect it - he saw it, because it was always meant to happen. No matter what happened before, it was the only outcome. Daenerys burnt King’s Landing because she wanted a bloodshed, because people did not want her as their Queen and did not welcome her as the Meereenese did, because she decided to rule by fear since she couldn’t have love, because she actuallys hates Westeros who does not bring her what she wants and only takes from her, and, maybe more importantly, because she can. She has dragons, she chose violence as she has always chosen, and she does not really care. She has the power to do what she wants, and because of that, King’s Landing was doomed either way.

So no, Sansa did not create chaos in Westeros. Her telling people or not had no influence on Daenerys’ actions and decisions. If anything, Sansa participated in creating another option than Daenerys, an option that the people across Westeros could choose - she created a way out, a possibility for Westeros to get rid of the Queen who would burn them all and to replace her with an honourable, kind, gentle man.

So no, Sansa did not create chaos in Westeros. Her telling people or not had no influence on Daenerys’ actions and decisions. If anything, Sansa participated in creating another option than Daenerys, an option that the people across Westeros could choose - she created a way out, a possibility for Westeros to get rid of the Queen who would burn them all and to replace her with an honourable, kind, gentle man.

trail.content_raw:
A lot of anti-Sansa, pro-Daenerys people out there are blaming the burning of King’s Landing on Sansa, arguing that Sansa is responsible for the chaos because she tried to overthrow Daenerys and put her in such an emotional state that she listened to anger, and that Sansa, more generally, put Westeros into chaos.

But these people forget one thing - or I should say, one person. 

They forgot Bran. They forgot the Three-Eyed Raven.

They forgot the one person in all of Westeros who knows what was, what is and what will be.

And yes, Bran is cold and detached this season. But yet, he is not deprived of humanity. He told the North about the dragon being turned into a wight, so that the North would get ready in consequence, instead of having to face an unexpected enemy that would have destroyed the living in one minute. He told Theon he was a good man before he died, even though he had no obligation to do it, and did it only to bring closure and comfort to Theon, a lost brother who was dying for him.

Bran is still human. If he could have saved King’s Landing, he would have.

He saw the destruction of the city in his prophetic visions, after all. In his visions, he got to see the dragon flying over King’s Landing, and then the throne room completely destroyed. He knew what would happen. It means that he had the means to prevent it, if there was a possibility to avoid the massacre.

And yet, we have Bran actively encouraging (and even pushing) Sam to tell the truth to Jon, therefore basically pushing for Jon as a candidate to the Iron Throne. After what happened in the last episode, I think it’s clear that Bran knew what would happen, and that they needed someone else, someone better.

But since Bran would have prevented the massacre if he had the means to, it means that Jon’s identity has no connection with Daenerys burning King’s Landing. Bran is able to see the links connecting causes to consequences, he is able to see the great chain of events. And in the great chain events, Jon knowing his identity was not the cause of Daenerys’s actions.

And here comes Sansa. Bran, able to see the bigger picture, does not oppose to Jon’s telling Sansa the truth. Actually, he agrees to telling it himself. And moreover, he actually lets Jon decide. “It’s your call.” 

This is a key element. Jon is free to tell his sisters, because Bran can see that whether they knew or not, it had no importance. That Sansa knew and told people, or that she did not know and therefore told no one, had no impact in the grand scheme of things. 

There was no connection Sansa tells people -> people turn against Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. There wasn’t even a connection Jon knows -> Jon tells Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. And since Bran did nothing that could be associated, even remotely, with preventing the massacre - telling Jon to take Rhaegal with him, or to protect Missandei, or to tell Daenerys something in particular, or telling Tyrion what to do - I think it is safe to argue that there was nothing Bran could do. 

The burning of King’s Landing was unavoidable. 

Yes, I know, Daenerys felt overwhelmed by everything that was happening to her and all her losses and she wanted a bloodshed - but she was bound to burn King’s Landing anyway. She saw it in Qarth, years ago. Bran saw it, even though future is a tricky issue that can always change, because people’s decisions affect it - he saw it, because it was always meant to happen. No matter what happened before, it was the only outcome. Daenerys burnt King’s Landing because she wanted a bloodshed, because people did not want her as their Queen and did not welcome her as the Meereenese did, because she decided to rule by fear since she couldn’t have love, because she actuallys hates Westeros who does not bring her what she wants and only takes from her, and, maybe more importantly, because she can. She has dragons, she chose violence as she has always chosen, and she does not really care. She has the power to do what she wants, and because of that, King’s Landing was doomed either way.

So no, Sansa did not create chaos in Westeros. Her telling people or not had no influence on Daenerys’ actions and decisions. If anything, Sansa participated in creating another option than Daenerys, an option that the people across Westeros could choose - she created a way out, a possibility for Westeros to get rid of the Queen who would burn them all and to replace her with an honourable, kind, gentle man.
trail.content:
A lot of anti-Sansa, pro-Daenerys people out there are blaming the burning of King’s Landing on Sansa, arguing that Sansa is responsible for the chaos because she tried to overthrow Daenerys and put her in such an emotional state that she listened to anger, and that Sansa, more generally, put Westeros into chaos.

But these people forget one thing - or I should say, one person. 

They forgot Bran. They forgot the Three-Eyed Raven.

They forgot the one person in all of Westeros who knows what was, what is and what will be.

And yes, Bran is cold and detached this season. But yet, he is not deprived of humanity. He told the North about the dragon being turned into a wight, so that the North would get ready in consequence, instead of having to face an unexpected enemy that would have destroyed the living in one minute. He told Theon he was a good man before he died, even though he had no obligation to do it, and did it only to bring closure and comfort to Theon, a lost brother who was dying for him.

Bran is still human. If he could have saved King’s Landing, he would have.

He saw the destruction of the city in his prophetic visions, after all. In his visions, he got to see the dragon flying over King’s Landing, and then the throne room completely destroyed. He knew what would happen. It means that he had the means to prevent it, if there was a possibility to avoid the massacre.

And yet, we have Bran actively encouraging (and even pushing) Sam to tell the truth to Jon, therefore basically pushing for Jon as a candidate to the Iron Throne. After what happened in the last episode, I think it’s clear that Bran knew what would happen, and that they needed someone else, someone better.

But since Bran would have prevented the massacre if he had the means to, it means that Jon’s identity has no connection with Daenerys burning King’s Landing. Bran is able to see the links connecting causes to consequences, he is able to see the great chain of events. And in the great chain events, Jon knowing his identity was not the cause of Daenerys’s actions.

And here comes Sansa. Bran, able to see the bigger picture, does not oppose to Jon’s telling Sansa the truth. Actually, he agrees to telling it himself. And moreover, he actually lets Jon decide. “It’s your call.” 

This is a key element. Jon is free to tell his sisters, because Bran can see that whether they knew or not, it had no importance. That Sansa knew and told people, or that she did not know and therefore told no one, had no impact in the grand scheme of things. 

There was no connection Sansa tells people -> people turn against Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. There wasn’t even a connection Jon knows -> Jon tells Daenerys -> Daenerys burns King’s Landing. And since Bran did nothing that could be associated, even remotely, with preventing the massacre - telling Jon to take Rhaegal with him, or to protect Missandei, or to tell Daenerys something in particular, or telling Tyrion what to do - I think it is safe to argue that there was nothing Bran could do. 

The burning of King’s Landing was unavoidable. 

Yes, I know, Daenerys felt overwhelmed by everything that was happening to her and all her losses and she wanted a bloodshed - but she was bound to burn King’s Landing anyway. She saw it in Qarth, years ago. Bran saw it, even though future is a tricky issue that can always change, because people’s decisions affect it - he saw it, because it was always meant to happen. No matter what happened before, it was the only outcome. Daenerys burnt King’s Landing because she wanted a bloodshed, because people did not want her as their Queen and did not welcome her as the Meereenese did, because she decided to rule by fear since she couldn’t have love, because she actuallys hates Westeros who does not bring her what she wants and only takes from her, and, maybe more importantly, because she can. She has dragons, she chose violence as she has always chosen, and she does not really care. She has the power to do what she wants, and because of that, King’s Landing was doomed either way.

So no, Sansa did not create chaos in Westeros. Her telling people or not had no influence on Daenerys’ actions and decisions. If anything, Sansa participated in creating another option than Daenerys, an option that the people across Westeros could choose - she created a way out, a possibility for Westeros to get rid of the Queen who would burn them all and to replace her with an honourable, kind, gentle man.
